thread.title: German yields retreat amid calls for more China stimulus, disinflation fears
thread.title_full: German yields retreat amid calls for more China stimulus, disinflation fears

title: German yields retreat amid calls for more China stimulus, disinflation fears
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Wed, Aug 26, 2015, 09:14 BST - UK Markets close in 7 hrs 16 mins German yields retreat amid calls for more China stimulus, disinflation fears Reuters - UK Focus â€“ 23 minutes ago 0.00 
By John Geddie 
LONDON, Aug 26 (Reuters) - German bond yields fell on Wednesday as the euphoria from China's rate cut ebbed and attention returned to weak oil prices and the troubled outlook for inflation. 
After surging more than 15 basis points to a three-week high on Tuesday after a string of solid economic releases and a shot of stimulus by the Chinese central bank, investors crept back into Europe's safe haven debt reversing the rise. 
This was partly disappointment that the boost to Chinese stocks proved short-lived, leading to calls for further stimulus which will only weaken the yuan and export disinflation to the rest of the world. 
But more importantly for investors, a slowdown in the world's second largest economy may reduce the chances of the U.S (Other OTC: UBGXF - news ) . raising interest rates for the first time in nearly a decade. 
"If China is unable to prevent a continued rapid slowdown, the implications will be felt around the world," said Clare Howarth of Oxford Economics. 
"Our scenario modelling indicates that a hard landing would prompt the Fed to delay raising rates, possibly for many months, with other monetary authorities following suit." 
German 10-year yields -- the euro zone benchmark -- dropped 4 bps in early trading back below 0.70 percent, but are still far from three-month lows of 0.51 percent hit on Monday when a slump in Chinese stocks sent investors scrambling for safety. 
Lower-rated euro zone equivalents from the likes of Portugal, Spain and Italy were down 1 bps at 2.73 percent , 2.10 percent and 1.98 percent . 
Many analysts said China's actions -- which saw it lower its one-year benchmark bank lending rate by 25 basis points to 4.6 percent and reduced the reserve requirement ratio by 50 basis points to 18.0 percent for most big banks -- will not be enough to shore up the slowdown in the economy. 
In fact many are calling for additional rate cuts to follow in the months ahead. 
Oil markets, which have been shaken by worries of weakening consumption and a supply gut, failed to take much of a boost from China's intervention with prices remaining just above 6-1/2-year lows. 
This has had a knock-on effect on the market's expectations for inflation around the world. Investors are still betting the euro zone, for instance, will head back into deflation in a year's time which will only up the pressure on the European Central Bank to expand its bond-buying programme. 
"Important links are likely to stem from potential disinflationary trends - both through exchange rate appreciation, but perhaps more importantly through the reduction in demand for commodities from emerging markets," said RBC (Other OTC: RBCI - news ) in a note to clients. 
"In this respect, the market measure of medium-term inflation expectations is worth keeping a close eye on." 
Germany, the euro zone's powerhouse economy, will release preliminary inflation data for August on Friday. (Editing by Keith Weir)
